History of Present Illness:
Mr ___ is a ___ w/hx of obesity, prior VF arrest s/p ICD,
HFrEF (LVEF ___, afib, AAA s/p repair, recently admitted for
gout flare of left knee, now presents with dyspnea and cough.

Patient was recently admitted in ___ for a gout flare of
left knee and right wrist. He was started on prednisone 40 mg 
and
colchicine 0.3 mg. Plan was to taper prednisone by 10 mg until 
at
10 mg daily. At that admission, he also had AoCKD with Cr to 3.0
(baseline 1.4-1.8). His torsemide 100 mg was held, and 
creatinine
improved to baseline. He was discharged on reduced dose of
torsemide 20 mg qOD. His dry weight is 410-412 lbs. He did not
tolerate lisinopril due to hyperkalemia.

He returned home on ___. Three days later (three days 
ago),
patient developed flu-like symptoms with cough productive of
yellow sputum, increased ___ edema, and dyspnea on exertion. He
denies any fevers and nausea/vomiting. He was taking torsemide 
20
mg daily at this time, which he says is much lower than the dose
he had been taking for months before that. 

Per EMS, the patient appeared acutely dyspneic, unable to speak
in full sentences, and requiring accessory muscle use. EMS exam
was consistent with expiratory wheezes and good tidal volume.  

On arrival to the ED, his initial VS were T 98.4, HR 110, BP
118/74, RR 22, O2 100% on RA. Exam notable for diffuse mild
wheezing, tachypnea, and bilateral edema (history of 
lymphedema).

Labs notable for WBC 10.6, hgb 11.6 (baseline), INR 1.6 (goal
___, Cr 1.6 (baseline 1.4-1.8), BUN 23, K 6.0 (improved to 
4.4),
lactate 2.0, BNP 3609, trop negative, VBG 7.___, UA with 9 
WBC,
few bacteria, moderate leuks. 

CXR showed:
Mild cardiomegaly with pulmonary vascular congestion. 
Focal opacities in right lower lobe and left upper lobe may
represent atelectasis or pneumonia in the appropriate clinical 
setting. 

He was given Lasix 80 mg IV x2 with good UOP for volume 
overload.
He was given levofloxacin for pneumonia concern. He was given
warfarin 3 mg x1 for afib. He was given benzonatate, 
guaifenesin,
and nebulizers for cough/dyspnea. His O2 saturation remained 
good
on room air. 

On arrival to the floor, patient is frustrated that he has had 
to
return to the hospital so soon after discharge. He reports his
breathing is slightly improved since getting Lasix IV in the ED.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
Negative except per HPI

___ TTE
CONCLUSION:
The left atrium is mildly dilated. No thrombus/mass is seen in 
the body of the left atrium (best excluded by
TEE) The interatrial septum is dynamic, but not frankly 
aneurysmal. There is moderate symmetric left
ventricular hypertrophy with a normal cavity size. There is 
suboptimal image quality to assess regional left
ventricular function. Overall left ventricular systolic function 
is mildly depressed. The visually estimated left
ventricular ejection fraction is 40-45%. Left ventricular 
cardiac index is depressed (less than 2.0 L/min/m2).
There is no resting left ventricular outflow tract gradient. 
Mildly dilated right ventricular cavity with mild global
free wall hypokinesis. The aortic sinus is mildly dilated with 
mildly dilated ascending aorta. The aortic arch
diameter is normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear 
structurally normal. There is no aortic valve stenosis.
There is no aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets 
appear structurally normal with no mitral valve
prolapse. There is trivial mitral regurgitation. The tricuspid 
valve leaflets appear structurally normal. There is
mild to moderate [___] tricuspid regurgitation. There is 
moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension.
There is no pericardial effusion.
IMPRESSION: Suboptimal image quality. Mpderate symmetric left 
ventricular hypertrpohy wtih normal cavity
size and mild global hypokinesis (unable to assess regional 
function). Moderate pulmonary artery systolic
hypertension. Right ventricular cavity dilation with free wall 
hypokinesis. Dilated ascending aorta.

 
Brief Hospital Course:
Mr ___ is a ___ w/hx of obesity, prior VF arrest s/p ICD, 
HFrEF (LVEF ___, afib, AAA s/p repair, recently admitted for 
gout flare of left knee, who presented with dyspnea and cough 
concerning for pneumonia and CHF exacerbation. His HFrEF 
exacerbation was found to be a combination of insufficient 
diuretic dosing as he was recently reduced from torsemide 100 mg 
daily to 20 mg qOD (due to ___, prednisone, and PNA. He was 
treated with multiple boluses if IV Lasix and he was 
successfully transitioned to PO diuretic at discharge. At 
admission, patient was hypoxic with a new productive cough c/f 
PNA. He was treated with 5 day course of levaquin (___). 
His metoprolol dose was uptitrated to 100mg metoprolol XL BID as 
he became tachy to 130s. His Coumadin was dosed daily and was 
therapeutic at dc. His discharge weight was 406 lbs and 
discharge Cr was 2.0.

# HFrEF exacerbation
Patient presented with dyspnea on exertion, cough, elevated BNP, 
significant edema, and CXR showing vascular congestion 
consistent with HFrEF exacerbation. Per patient, EF ___ in 
___, with EF 40-45% on repeat TTE this admission. 
Likely trigger for exacerbation was insufficient diuretic dosing 
as he was recently reduced from torsemide 100 mg daily to 20 mg 
qOD (due to ___, prednisone, and PNA (see below). He was 
treated with multiple boluses of IV Lasix and was successfully 
transitioned to PO diuretic at discharge. He was also started on 
isordil and hydralazine for afterload reduction and Lopressor 
dose was uptitrated for atrial fibrillation (see below).
- PRELOAD: Torsemide 60mg daily
- AFTERLOAD: Isordil 10mg TID, Hydralazine 10mg TID 
- NHBK: Metoprolol succinate 100mg BID
- RASI: Did not tolerate lisinopril at last admission due to
hyperkalemia, which he also had this admission

# Pneumonia: 
Patient presented with DOE, SOB and productive cough with 
hypoxia on admission. Al with high-normal WBC and cough 
productive of yellow sputum, and CXR with RLL and LUL 
consolidation consistent with pneumonia. He was managed with 
Levofloxacin 750 mg daily x5 days (day 1= ___, benzonatate, 
and guaifenisin.

# Chronic Atrial fibrillation: 
Patient was rate controlled in afib this admission. CHADSVASC of 
1. Metoprolol was uptitrated given frequent bursts to 130s. 
Discharged on 100 mg metoprolol succinate BID. Coumadin was 
dosed daily and INR was therapeutic (2.6) at discharge. ___ 
___ clinic was contacted prior to ___, and will 
continue to draw INR at home and monitor INR. Discharged on 3mg 
Coumadin daily.

# Hyperkalemia: 
# CKD: Patient has hyperkalemia iso CKD and acidosis that 
improved with diuresis. Meds were renally dosed.

# Acute L knee pain secondary to

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,  
 It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ 
___!  
 WHY WAS I IN THE HOSPITAL?  
 ==========================  
 - You were admitted because of shortness of breath and a cough. 
This was felt to be due to a condition called heart failure, 
where your heart does not pump hard enough and fluid backs up 
into your lungs as well as an infection of your lungs called 
pneumonia.
  
 WHAT HAPPENED IN THE HOSPITAL?  
 ==============================  
 - You were given a diuretic medication through the IV to help 
get the fluid out.  The infection in your lungs was treated with 
an antibiotic. You improved considerably and were ready to leave 
the hospital 
 
 WHAT SHOULD I DO WHEN I GO HOME?  
 ================================
- Your weight at discharge is 406 lbs. Please weigh yourself 
today at home and use this as your new baseline  
 - Please weigh yourself every day in the morning. Call your 
doctor if your weight goes up by more than 3 lbs.
  
 Thank you for allowing us to be involved in your care, we wish 
you all the best!  
 Your ___ Healthcare Team

Imaging:
Head CT ___:
FINDINGS: There is a 2.8 x 3.2 x 2.3 cm mildly hyperdense right 
frontal 
lesion near the vertex with a hypodense interior that avidly 
enhances. There does not appear to be cortical erosion of bone 
or hyperostosis. There is no pronounced perilesional edema. No 
other mass is seen. There is small calcification in the left 
temporal lobe. There is no shift of normally midline structures. 
Mastoid air cells are clear. Visualized paranasal sinuses are 
clear. The orbits appear unremarkable. 
IMPRESSION: Right frontal enhancing mass with necrotic interior 
most likely a brain neoplasm. Consider MR for further 
characterization. 

CT Torso ___:
CT CHEST: The airways are patent up to subsegmental level. There 
are no 
concerning airspace opacities, or pulmonary nodules. There is no 
pleural 
effusion. There are no pathologically enlarged lymph nodes in 
the mediastinum, hilum, or axilla according to CT size criteria. 
There are subcentimeter lymph nodes in the axilla; however do 
not meet the CT criteria for pathological enlargement. Calcified 
nodes are also seen in the mediastinum. The heart size is 
normal. There is no pericardial effusion.   
CT ABDOMEN: The liver, pancreas, spleen appear normal. The 
adrenal glands 
are normal. The kidneys enhance symmetrically and excrete 
contrast 
symmetrically with bilateral hypodensities too small to 
characterize, likely small renal cysts. The gallbladder appears 
normal with gallstones within. There are no pathologically 
enlarged lymph nodes in the retroperitoneum or mesentery. The 
loops of small and large bowel appear normal. The stomach 
appears normal. There is no free fluid. There is no free air.   
CT PELVIS: The urinary bladder and ureters appear normal. The 
sigmoid and 
loops of small bowel within the pelvis appear normal. There is 
no free fluid in the pelvis. There are no enlarged lymph nodes 
in the pelvic or inguinal area according to CT size criteria. 
OSSEOUS STRUCTURES: No suspicious lytic or sclerotic lesions are 
seen in the bones. 
IMPRESSION: 
1. No evidence of primary tumor in the CT torso. 
2. Cholelithiasis without evidence of cholecystitis. 

MRI Head ___:
FINDINGS: There is a 2.7 cm round circumscribed extra-axial mass 
at the right vertex, depressing the paracentral lobule 
inferiorly. There is mild 
associated vasogenic edema in the adjacent frontal and parietal 
lobes. The 
mass demonstrates isointensity on the pre-contrast T1-weighted 
images, mild hyperintensity on T2-weighted images, neither fast 
nor slow diffusion, and predominantly solid enhancement with a 
small non-enhancing center on the postcontrast T1-weighted 
images. A small portion of the non-enhancing center demonstrates 
low signal on the gradient-echo images without evidence of 
blooming, which is somewhat more likely to represent 
calcification rather than blood products. Faint hyperdensity 
within the mass on the preceding CT scan is compatible with 
either calcification or blood products. Overall, the mass is 
most consistent with a meningioma.  
No other intra-axial or extra-axial masses are seen. The 
ventricles are 
normal in size and configuration. There is no acute infarction. 
The major 
arterial flow voids are unremarkable. 
IMPRESSION: 2.7 cm extra-axial mass at the right vertex, most 
likely a 
meningioma, with mild vasogenic edema in the paracentral lobule.

Discharge Instructions:
General Instructions/Information

•Have a friend/family member check your incision daily for signs 
of infection.
•Take your pain medicine as prescribed.
•Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, 
or excessive bending.
•You may wash your hair only after sutures have been removed. 
•You may shower before this time using a shower cap to cover 
your head.
•Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain 
medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking 
an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) 
while taking narcotic pain medication.
•Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any 
anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and 
Ibuprofen etc.  
•You have been prescribed Dilantin (Phenytoin) for anti-seizure 
medicine, take it as prescribed and follow up with laboratory 
blood drawing in one week.  This can be drawn at your PCP’s 
office, but please have the results faxed to ___. 
•You are being sent home on steroid medication, make sure you 
are taking a medication to protect your stomach (Prilosec, 
Protonix, or Pepcid), as these medications can cause stomach 
irritation.  Make sure to take your steroid medication with 
meals, or a glass of milk. 
•Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at your 
post-operative office visit.
•Make sure to continue to use your incentive spirometer while at 
home.

CALL YOUR SURGEON IMMEDIATELY IF YOU EXPERIENCE ANY OF THE 
FOLLOWING

•New onset of tremors or seizures.
•Any confusion or change in mental status. 
•Any numbness, tingling, weakness in your extremities.
•Pain or headache that is continually increasing, or not 
relieved by pain medication.
•Any signs of infection at the wound site: increasing redness, 
increased swelling, increased tenderness, or drainage.
•Fever greater than or equal to 101° F.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mr. ___ is a ___ right-handed man with history 
notable for atrial fibrillation (on apixaban), HTN, HLD, CAD, 
OSA (on CPAP), C7-T1 radiculopathy s/p ESI, bipolar II disorder, 
and subclinical hypothyroidism who presented to the ___ 
emergency department after an episode of dizziness, syncope, and 
subsequent left-sided weakness. Due to the left-sided weakness, 
neurology was consulted with concern for stroke. He was admitted 
to the neurology service. Notably, he has had several prior 
episodes of presyncope and vertigo provoked by climbing stairs 
at his work, but not in other settings and not. Without 
provocation

Neurologic exam was generally unremarkable, with full strength 
throughout. There was some give way on the left side. 
___ maneuver was negative. CT scan of the head, and CTA 
of the head neck were unrevealing for any acute pathology. Lab 
work did not suggest any evidence of hypovolemia or other 
significant derangement. Orthostatic vital signs were negative. 
Telemetry monitoring did not capture any arrhythmia. He was able 
to ambulate around the floor, as well as up and down stairs, 
without any reproduction of his symptoms.

Overall, his symptoms of presyncope and vertigo were not 
suggestive of stroke. MRI brain was therefore not obtained. 
Based on his reassuring exam, there is no immediately apparent 
neurologic diagnosis to explain his symptoms. As he has had 
extensive cardiac evaluation in the past, this was not repeated 
here. We recommend he continue to follow with his primary care 
doctor as well as cardiologist given the exertional nature of 
his symptoms. Referral to ENT could also be considered.

medication list for details). As part of our safe opioid

transitioned to oral pain medication when tolerating PO diet.

therapy was consulted for mobilization OOB to ambulate.  The 
patient become tachycardic and febrile on POD#1 after the first 
surgery.  This was thought to be due to a standar post-operative 
fever. The patient was monitored and taken to the second stage 
of the surgery without complication. The patient remained 
tachycardic and febrile post-operatively from the second surgery 
and a fever work-up was initiated. UA was negative. CXR was 
negative. Blood cultures were negative. The patient remained 
asymptomatic throughout.  The patient received one unit of pRBCs 
post-operatively for anemia and her heart rate improved.  The 
patient developed a slight ileus on POD#3 from the second 
surgery.  Due to the persistent tachycardia, fever and ileus, a 
CT abdomen and pelvis was obtained and the patient's abdomen was 
evaluated by general surgery.  General surgery felt the 
abdominal exam was consistent with ileus and there was little 
concern for an acute intra-abdominal process. CT demonstated a 
retroperitoneal hematoma consistent with the post-operative 
state.  Medicine and Infectious Diseases were consulted for 
fever of unkown origin.  The patient was emperically started on 
Vancomycin and Zosyn.  The remainder of the work-up was 
unremarkable.  The patient become afebrile.  Antibiotics were 
held at the recommendations of the consulting services and the 
patient remained afebrile off antibiotics. At the time of 
discharge, the patient was asymptomatic, mobilizing 
independently, afebrile off antibiotics.  The sourcfe of the

# ___ rash: On admission, met criteria for severe sepsis 
with tachypnea in ED to high ___, fever, 7% bands on diff, 
lactate>2, change in mental status, and areas of mottled skin. 
He was intubated for respiratory compromise and transfered to 
the MICU. Most likely source of infection was skin/soft tissue 
since this was his predominant complaint. CT and MRI of the 
lower extremities were not consistent with necrotizing fascitis. 
Skin continued to worsen over the first 3 days of hospital 
course, and developed dramatic bullae in dependent regions of 
the LEs. Paracentesis with 250 polys implied either a primary or 
secondary intra-abdominal process. Patient received albumin on 
diagnosis and 2 days later for renal prophylaxis in the setting 
of SBP. Blood cultures from admission eventually grew 
pansensitive Strep penumonia and he was initially managed on 
vancomycin, ceftriaxone and clindamycin, which was changed to 
vanco/cefepime/clindamycin with ID input. TTE and TEE were 
negative for endocarditis. No evidence of embolic phenomenon 
were noted. Final etiology was not clear at the time of transfer 
from the ICU, but ID felt patient likely had SBP which seeded 
patient hematogenously, which led to embolic phenomenon to the 
lower extremities. The ICU team felt that patient may have 
started with a soft tissue infection, which led to hemeatogenous 
spread, which may have then led to seeding of the peritoneal 
fluid. Strep pneumo has been described as a rare cause of 
cellulitis in case reports. Workup also included negative ANCA, 
relatively normal complement, and negative CMV. When final 
speciation from blood culture returned patient was transitioned 
to Ceftriaxone alone prior to transfer to the floor. Pt was 
afebrile while on ___ 10 with stable vital signs. Wound care 
continued to follow patient and daily dressing changes were 
initated. While on ___ 10 patient complained of right lower 
back/upper buttock pain. Dermatology evaluated patient and felt 
that the dermatomal distribution of the pain warranted VZV 
prohylaxis. Patient was swiftly transferred to ___ 5 to protect 
transplant patients from VZV exposure. He was eventually found 
not to have VZV and antivirals were stopped.  The patient's 
distal lower extremity wounds were managed with antibiotics 
including the above Ceftriaxone and vancomycin which were 
eventually discontinued and Daptomycin was started and stopped 
at time of discharge.
.  
#. Altered mental Status: Likely multifactorial related to 
infection +/- hepatic encephalopathy and narcotics received in 
ED with decreased ability to metabolize narcotics in setting of 
liver disease. Improved after extubation with lactulose and 
rifaximin.
.  
#. Hyponatremia: Concerning for hepatorenal vs hypovolemic 
hyponatremia. Diff also includes SIADH from pain. Improved with 
fluids while in the ICU. Because of his hypersosmolar urine on 
the floor, he was presumed to have SIADH and he eventually was 
restricted to 1500ml fluids per day on the floor and his 
hyponatremia reversed. He developed hyponatremia later in his 
hospital course which was again concerning for hepatorenal 
syndrome. He was given IV concentrated albumin and his sodium 
remained stable and borderline low at time of discharge.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ woman w/PMHx HTN, HL, CVA and recent dz limited small cell 
lung CA s/p XRT and taxol/carboplatin, admitted with new dx mets 
to rib and liver. Odynophagia complicated her management. She 
declined during the course of the hospitalization, and after 
extensive discussion was transitioned to comfort measures only 
on ___ and the patient passed away on ___
.
# Metastatic small cell lung cancer
The patient's Oncologist spoke with her shortly after admission, 
making it clear that further chemotherapy or radiation were 
unlikely to offer significant benefit.  He also indicated that 
he felt she only had "weeks" to live.  The patient was seen by 
Palliative Care, and after discussions with her, and her family 
(health care proxy and another niece) it was decided to 
transition her to comfort measures only.  She was treated with 
IV therapies (analgesics, antiemetics, anxiolytics, etc.) given 
her inability to swallow (significant pain due to radiation 
esophagitis).  She was initially placed on IV fluids to keep her 
hydrated, but these were stopped on ___ when it was felt 
they were worsening her comfort (she was getting "gurgly" per 
nursing).  The patient was followed by inpatient hospice who 
provided social support to the family.  On ___ the patient 
expired.
.
# Possible candidal esophagitis with thrush
The patient was initially empirically treated with IV 
fluconazole, but given the change in the goals to comfort 
measures only, it was stopped since it had not seemed to offer 
comfort.
.
#Pleural effusion with mild coagulopathy
A thoracentesis was considered, but shortness of breath was not 
a prominent symptom and given her coagulopathy (elevated PTT, 
possibly due to liver lesions), this was not done.
.
# Possible ascites with abd discomfort
A paracentesis was considered, but when her goals of care 
changed as noted above, especially given her coagulopathy, this 
was not done, and instead her symptoms of pain were treated with 
narcotics.
.
# Constipation
The patient was given bisacodyl PRN and standing senna and 
docusate.
.
# HTN, HL, h/o CVA
Given the patient's goals of care, these issues were not 
specifically treated.
.
# Transitional Issues:
-The patients PCP was informed of the patients death in addition 
to the patients HCP, ___.  She confirmed that the 
family did not want a autopsy
.

Discharge Instructions:
INSTRUCTIONS AFTER HAND SURGERY:

- You were in the hospital for hand surgery. It is normal to 
feel tired or "washed out" after surgery, and this feeling 
should improve over the first few days to week. 
- Resume your regular activities as tolerated, but please follow 
your weight bearing precautions strictly at all times.

ACTIVITY AND WEIGHT BEARING:
- Non weight bearing right upper extremity

MEDICATIONS:
  1)  Take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours around the clock. This is 
an over the counter medication.
  2)  Add oxycodone as needed for increased pain. Aim to wean 
off this medication in 1 week or sooner.  This is an example on 
how to wean down:
Take 1 tablet every 4 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 6 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every 8 hours as needed x 2 days, 
then 1 tablet every 12 hours as needed x 1 day,
then 1 tablet every before bedtime as needed x 1 day.  
Then continue with Tylenol for pain.
  3)  Do not stop the Tylenol until you are off of the narcotic 
medication.
  4)  Per state regulations, we are limited in the amount of 
narcotics we can prescribe. If you require more, you must 
contact the office to set up an appointment because we cannot 
refill this type of pain medication over the phone. 
  5)  Narcotic pain relievers can cause constipation, so you 
should drink eight 8oz glasses of water daily and continue 
following the bowel regimen as stated on your medication 
prescription list. These meds (senna, colace, miralax) are over 
the counter and may be obtained at any pharmacy.
  6)  Do not drink alcohol, drive a motor vehicle, or operate 
machinery while taking narcotic pain relievers.
  7)  Please take all medications as prescribed by your 
physicians at discharge.
  8)  Continue all home medications unless specifically 
instructed to stop by your surgeon.
      
WOUND CARE:
- You may shower. No baths or swimming for at least 4 weeks.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.
- Incision may be left open to air unless actively draining. If 
draining, you may apply a gauze dressing secured with paper 
tape.
- If you have a splint in place, splint must be left on until 
follow up appointment unless otherwise instructed. Do NOT get 
splint wet.

DANGER SIGNS:
Please call your PCP or surgeon's office and/or return to the 
emergency department if you experience any of the following:
- Increasing pain that is not controlled with pain medications
- Increasing redness, swelling, drainage, or other concerning 
changes in your incision
- Persistent or increasing numbness, tingling, or loss of 
sensation
- Fever ___ 101.4
- Shaking chills
- Chest pain
- Shortness of breath
- Nausea or vomiting with an inability to keep food, liquid, 
medications down
- Any other medical concerns

site of pancreas transplantation with elevated lipases (1785) 
and amylase (684) and biopsy significant for mild transplant 
rejection.  Patient was treated with four doses of ATG 1.5mg/kg 
daily.  She was pretreated with steroid, benadryl and tylenol.  
Her platelets and wbc were monitored daily as ATG can cause 
thrombocytopenia and leukopenia.  Her platelets never decreased 
below 100, and wbc remained above 3, and so the dose of the ATG 
was not changed.  Her amylase and lipase trended down to 85 and 
32 on day of discharge.  A CD3 level on discharge was 2.3% and 
the patient did not require further ATG doses.  She was 
continued on her home dose of prednisone 5mg daily and bactrim.  
She was started on a 30 day course of Valganciclovir for CMV 
prophylaxis and one month of Nystatin.
.
S/p Renal transplant: Her creatine improved from 1.6 to 1.2.

and bactrim prophylaxis.  Tacrolimus levels checked every 
morning.

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ female with history of AML 
s/p 7+3 in CR + ___ ___ AML/DC fusion vaccine trial 
receiving MiDAC consolidation complicated by staph epidermidis 
bacteremia with presumed endocarditis, bilateral DVTs (off 
therapeutic lovenox) who presents for abdominal pain and found 
to have perforated diverticulitis. The patient was medically 
managed with intravenous antibiotics and bowel rest and 
subsequently improved. Diet was slowly advanced without issues. 
The patient remained afebrile and hemodynamically stable. 

# Perforated Acute Diverticulitis
# Neutropenia
Presented with worsening acute abdominal pain since being 
discharged following the second cycle of MiDAC. CT abd/pelvis 
showed a perforated acute diverticulitis. Evaluated by surgery 
and BMT in ED, and the decision was made to pursue conservative 
management with IV antibiotics. She was initially started on 
vancomycin/zosyn overnight, switched to meropenem due to a 
cefepime allergy. Patient initially placed on bowel rest and 
then advanced to regular diet without issues. Her pain resolved 
with time, though 1 week later, while neutropenic, she developed 
an isolated temperature of 100.5 in the setting of 48 hours of 
crampy "gas like" LLQ abdominal pain. Other vitals were stable. 
Repeat CT A/P with PO contrast demonstrated worsening of the 
diverticulitis and perforation. Surgery consulted, recommended 
surgery on this admission. However, given patient preference and 
high risk of surgery with neutropenia, we continued a 
conservative course, re-added vancomycin to her regimen for 
febrile neutropenia and made her NPO; remained HD stable and 
pain free. Decided not to use neupogen given again patient 
preference but also risk of bowel perf with neupogen. 7 days 
later, once her neutrophils recovered and reached > 3000, repeat 
CT A/P with oral contrast showed improvement in bowel edema and 
perforation. Discharged after 24 hours on oral cipro/flagyl and 
with close follow up to oncology and instructions to call if any 
concern for C. Diff. 

# Acute Myelogenous Leukemia
Normal karyotype, Flt3 ITD negative, low frequency mutations in 
IDH2 and DNMT3A consistent with intermediate risk. Enrolled in 
vaccine trial ___ and s/p 2 cycles MiDAC consolidation. 
During admission, she required 1 platelet transfusion and 2 pRBC 
transfusions. She was neutropenic with a nadir to 50 on ___ and 
increased to a slight leukocytosis on discharge. 

#Leukocytosis: Increased to ___ on day of discharge. She is 
asymptomatic and her abdominal exam is benign. No urinary 
symptoms, respiratory symptoms or abdominal pain. She was 
instructed to be aware of c. Diff as a possibility given her 
antibiotic course. 

# Anemia
Hgb 7.0 on admission, downtrended to 6.7. Received 1u pRBC in 
the emergency department with appropriate response. Anemia was 
more chronic, likely secondary to malignancy and chemotherapy. 
No evidence of active bleed.

Discharge Instructions:
Wound Care:
- Keep Incision clean and dry.
- You can get the wound wet or take a shower starting from 7 
days after surgery, but no baths or swimming for at least 4 
weeks.
- Dry sterile dresssing may be changed daily.  No dressing is 
needed if wound continues to be non-draining.
- Any stitches or staples that need to be removed will be taken 
out at your 2-week follow up appointment.

Activity:
- Continue to be weight-bearing as tolerated on your left leg, 
with anterior precautions.
- Elevate left leg to reduce swelling and pain.

Other Instructions
- Resume your regular diet.
- Please check electroyltes, including phosphorus and magnesium 
in addition to a Basic Metabolic Panel, and replete 
appropriately.
- Avoid nicotine products to optimize healing.
- Resume your home medications. Take all medications as 
instructed.
- Continue taking the Lovenox to prevent blood clots.
- You have also been given Additional Medications to control 
your pain.  Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so plan ahead.  You can either have them mailed 
to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on ___. 
 We are not allowed to call in narcotic (oxycontin, oxycodone, 
percocet) prescriptions to the pharmacy.   In addition, we are 
only allowed to write for pain medications for 90 days from the 
date of surgery.

alcohol while taking narcotic medications.  Do not operate any 
motor vehicle or machinery while taking narcotic pain 
medications.  Taking more than recommended may cause serious 
breathing problems.

On presentation, the patient was evaluated and felt to be at an 
increased risk of harm to herself and/or others based upon her 
active psychosis.  Her static factors noted at that time include 
history of mental illness, history of substance abuse, and 
chronic medical illness.   The modifiable risk factors were also 
addressed at that time, included disorganized and unpredictable 
behavior, limited social supports, poor reality testing, lack of 
engagement with outpatient providers, and medication 
nonadherence.  Finally, the patient is being discharged with 
many protective risk factors, lack of suicidal ideation, 
improvement in her psychotic symptoms, increased support from 
her daughter.  Overall, based on the totality of our assessment 
at this time, the patient is thought to be at her baseline 
moderate risk of self-harm/suicide and is not thought to be at 
an acutely elevated risk. Our Prognosis of this patient is 
guarded given her history of medication non-compliance and poor 
previous follow-up with outpatient providers.

Brief Hospital Course:
Mrs. ___ is a ___ year old ___ speaking woman with a 
history of hypertension who presented with deep venous 
thrombosis in her left distal femoral vein. 

# Left Distal Femoral Deep Venous Thrombosis -
    Patient noted that she had a DVT in the same location about 
one year ago but was treated only with two weeks of heparin drip 
in ___ rather than a full six months of anticoagulation.  
Her current DVT in the distal femoral vein on the left appears 
to be in the same location and may be the same DVT she had last 
year.  She exhibited no signs of pulmonary embolism. She did not 
have chest pain, shortness of breath, or tachycardia.
    Upon admission and arrival to the floor, the patient was 
started on Enoxaparin 1mg/kg BID dosing as a bridge to coumadin, 
and the heparin drip was stopped.  The patient was started on 
4mg warfarin and given a lab slip to have her INR checked in two 
days; the lab result will be faxed to her primary care doctor's 
office, and the patient will follow up this week with her 
primary care doctor.  She should continue on coumadin for at 
least six months. 
    If the patient has had two separate DVTs in the past year, 
she would need a prolonged course of coumadin and would be at 
10% increased risk of having a cancer.  She should followup with 
outpatient screening for her age, including mammogram and 
colonoscopy. The patient does note a painful lump in her breast 
and has resisted mammogram, per daughter.

# Hypertension - 
Patient takes atenolol and enalapril at home for blood pressure 
control. Neither the patient nor her daughter remembered the 
dosing, and there was no record of her medications in the ___ 
medical records, so she was given low doses of both medicines, 
which did not adequately control her blood pressures.  Her 
systolic blood pressures were in the 140s-150s.

Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

Discharge Instructions:
Wound Care:
•Remove dressing in 2 days.
•Keep steri-strips in place until they fall off or they are 
removed at your first post-operative visit.
•Showering in 3 days is fine; be sure to pat the incision dry 
afterwards.
•Do not scrub the area; just allow water/soap to wash over you.
•Do not bath or swim until approved by surgeon.

Ice:
•We recommend that you use the ice wrap/cryocuff on a 
consistent basis for the first 24–48 hours. This will help 
reduce post-operative swelling. After that, use as necessary. 
•Use a cloth between the ice and your skin.  DO NOT place ice 
directly on skin as this may cause ___ bite.  Do not leave ice 
wrap or cold therapy on for more than 20 minutes without 
checking your skin

Sling & Weight bearing status:
•With a Rotator Cuff Repair, you will be placed in a sling..
•You need to wear the sling for at least 4 weeks depending on 
the size/type of your repair (see above).  It should only be 
removed for showering and for your exercises.
•You should not bear weight with your arm or use your arm to 
lift anything until 3 months after surgery.

Physical Therapy: 
•Formal physical therapy will be ordered by your orthopedic 
surgeon in the form of a written prescription at your first 
follow up appt. You will also receive a therapy protocol form.  
Following a Rotator Cuff Repair, you should start formal 
physical therapy after your first post-operative appointment.  
The prescription and protocol should be given to a physical 
therapist of your choice so you can begin your program as 
directed under close supervision of your surgeon.
•You should call ahead of time and set up a ___ appointment for 
___ days after your first post-operative appointment. 

Pain Control:
Day of Surgery
•You have been given a regional anesthetic block prior to your 
operation.  This will wear off in the evening following your 
surgery.
•You may find it beneficial to sleep in a recliner or propped 
up on pillows for the first several days after surgery.

Narcotics
•You have been prescribed 1 narcotic pain medications.  It is 
important to stay ahead of your pain.
••You should take the pain medication  for pain not controlled 
by the Morphine and for pain once the Morphine is finished.   
You may call ___ for a refill as needed.  Please review 
a copy of our narcotics policy which is attached.
•Use the medication only as prescribed. Take it with food.
•Do not drive or use any type of heavy machinery, drink 
alcohol, make any life-changing or legal decisions (i.e. sign a 
will), or participate in activities that require a lot of 
physical skill.
•Take a stool softener, such as Colace, while taking the 
narcotic medication, because narcotics may cause constipation.

Non- Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Medications:
•You may take an over the counter non-steroidal 
anti-inflammatory such as Motrin, Advil, Ibuprofen or Aleve for 
additional pain control for two weeks and then as needed.
•Take only if you do not have a contraindication to taking this 
medication (i.e. allergy to the medication, stomach ulcers or 
kidney problems).
•Take this medication with food, and try to stagger the times 
you take this medication with your pain medication.  This may 
help decrease the chance of stomach upset.

Driving:
•You may resume driving when approved by your orthopedic 
surgeon.  We do not recommend driving while wearing a sling.
.

 you should not begin pendulum exercises until instructed.  You 
should remain in your sling at all times.  It may only be 
removed to bend + straighten your elbow ___ times a day and for 
showering.

Return to Work:
•You may return to work as soon as you are comfortable.  This 
is dependent on your job type.  You will not be able to do any 
work with your arm for 6 weeks post-op.  You will not be able to

Discharge Instructions:
 
 

You have undergone the following operation: ANTERIOR/POSTERIOR 
Lumbar Decompression With Fusion
 

 
Immediately after the operation:
 

 
-Activity: You should not lift anything greater than 10 lbs for 
2 weeks. You will be more comfortable if you do not sit or stand 
more than ~45 minutes without getting up and walking around.
 

 
-Rehabilitation/ Physical Therapy: 
 
o2-3 times a day you should go for a walk for ___ minutes as 
part of your recovery. You can walk as much as you can tolerate. 

 
oLimit any kind of lifting.
 

 
-Diet: Eat a normal healthy diet. You may have some constipation 
after surgery. You have been given medication to help with this 
issue.
 

 
-Brace: You have been given a brace. This brace is to be worn 
for comfort when you are walking. You may take it off when 
sitting in a chair or while lying in bed.
 

 
-Wound Care: Remove the dressing in 2 days. If the incision is 
draining cover it with a new sterile dressing. If it is dry then 
you can leave the incision open to the air. Once the incision is 
completely dry (usually ___ days after the operation) you may 
take a shower. Do not soak the incision in a bath or pool. If 
the incision starts draining at anytime after surgery, do not 
get the incision wet. Cover it with a sterile dressing. Call the 
office. 
 

 
-You should resume taking your normal home medications. No 
NSAIDs.
 

 
-You have also been given Additional Medications to control your 
pain. Please allow 72 hours for refill of narcotic 
prescriptions, so please plan ahead. You can either have them 
mailed to your home or pick them up at the clinic located on 
___ 2. We are not allowed to call in or fax narcotic 
prescriptions (oxycontin, oxycodone, percocet) to your pharmacy. 
In addition, we are only allowed to write for pain medications 
for 90 days from the date of surgery.
 

 
Please call the office if you have a fever>101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit and/or drainage from your wound.
 

Physical Therapy:
Ambulate as tolerated/ unable to bear weight secondary to leg 
weakness s/p spinal cord injury/ USe tlso when OOB
Treatment Frequency:
Keep incisions clean and dry/ OOB as tolerated

Discharge Instructions:
Division of Vascular and Endovascular Surgery
Lower Extremity Angioplasty/Stent Discharge Instructions

Medications:
•Take Aspirin 81mg once daily 
•If instructed, take Plavix (Clopidogrel) 75mg once daily
•Continue all other medications you were taking before surgery, 
unless otherwise directed
•You make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for any 
post procedure pain or discomfort

What to expect when you go home:
It is normal to have slight swelling of the legs:
•Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ 
pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at 
night
•Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated
•It is normal to feel tired and have a decreased appetite, your 
appetite will return with time 
•Drink plenty of fluids and eat small frequent meals
•It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing
•To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

What activities you can and cannot do:
•When you go home, you may walk and go up and down stairs
•You may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision, 
rinse and pat dry)
•Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or 
band aid over the area that is draining, as needed
•No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for 
1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal)
•After 1 week, you may resume sexual activity
•After 1 week, gradually increase your activities and distance 
walked as you can tolerate
•No driving until you are no longer taking pain medications
•Call and schedule an appointment to be seen in ___ weeks for 
post procedure check and ultrasound 

What to report to office:
•Numbness, coldness or pain in lower extremities 
•Temperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours
•New or increased drainage from incision or white, yellow or 
green drainage from incisions
•Bleeding from groin puncture site

SUDDEN, SEVERE BLEEDING OR SWELLING (Groin puncture site)
•Lie down, keep leg straight and have someone apply firm 
pressure to area for 10 minutes. If bleeding stops, call 
vascular office ___. If bleeding does not stop, call 
___ for transfer to closest Emergency Room.

impair your ability to drive a motor vehicle or operate 
machinery safely. You MUST  refrain from such activities while 
taking these medications. 

 

 

Please call your doctor or return to the emergency room if you 
have any of the following:
 

 * You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
 tightness.
 
* New or worsening cough or wheezing.
 
* If you are vomiting and cannot keep in fluids or your 
 medications.
 
* You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, 
 diarrhea or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry 
 mouth, rapid heartbeat or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.
 
* You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
 bowel movement.
 

* You have shaking chills, or a fever greater than 101.5 (F) 
 degrees or 38(C) degrees.
 
* Any serious change in your symptoms, or any new symptoms that 
 concern you.

meds

*You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or 
tightness.

*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.

*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
medications.

*You are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, 
or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include dry mouth, rapid 
heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing.

bowel movement.

*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
urine, or experience a discharge.

*You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees 
Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius.

you.

advised not to take a particular medication. Also, please take 
any new medications as prescribed.

per day, and drink adequate amounts of fluids. Avoid lifting 
weights greater than ___ lbs until you follow-up with your 
surgeon.

appointment.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the hospital with nausea, 
vomitting,and abdominal distention. A ___ tube was 
placed while the patient was in the emergency room with removal 
of 1.5 liters of feculent drainage.  THe patient underwent a cat 
scan of the abdomen which showed a small bowel obstruction with 
relative transition point in the right lower quadrant.  Based on 
these findings, the patient was placed on bowel rest and given 
intravenous fluids.  He underwent serial abdominal examinations. 
His white blood cell count was closely monitored.  The patient 
transitioned to clear liquids on HD #6 and gradually advanced to 
a regular diet.  His abdominal assessment continued and there 
was no recurrence of abdominal pain.  His foley catheter was 
removed but required replacement after the patient failed to 
void.  He resumed his home medications, including his coumadin, 
with close monitoring of his INR.  His white blood cell count 
normalized.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

You were admitted to the hospital with nausea, abdominal pain 
and pain with swallowing. You had a CT scan done of your abdomen 
which showed significant constipation. You were given enemas and 
oral medications with relief of your constipation and 
improvement in your nausea. It is VERY important that you 
continue to take your medications for constipation to prevent 
recurrent abdominal pain.

In terms of your pain with swallowing, this was thought to be 
secondary to recurrent esophagitis. You were treated with 
omeprazole (an acid suppression medication), sucralafate and 
maalox/lidocaine mouth wash with improvement in your pain. Your 
nausea was treated with zofran and you were tolerating food and

Brief Hospital Course:
REASON FOR HOSPITAL ADMISSION:
.
___ y/o M h/o CAD s/p stent to proximal RCA ___, HTN, HL, p/w 
acute onset chest pain, found to have STE in inferior leads, 
transferred to ___ for cardiac cath. 
.

HOSPITAL COURSE: 
.
#Unstable Angina- Pt presented with chest pain; on arrival was 
taken to cath and found to have completely clean coronaries. Pt 
with history of CAD s/p RCA stent ___. Pt had not been having 
chest pain at home until the night prior to admission and has 
not had to use nitroglycerin at home in many years. Pain began 
at rest which pointed away from a cardiac etiology. It was 
relieved with nitro in the ED, but EKG showed changes c/w 
inferior wall ischemia. Cath revealed clean coronaries, 
follow-up EKG showing the majority of EKG changes had resolved. 
Pericarditis was considered in the differential, or possibly a 
small clot that had auto-lysed or travelled more distally. It 
was felt that the most convincing explanation was a vasospastic 
process as he did exhibit self-reversing ST elevations (duly 
noted that vasospasm classically occurs in young women. Still, 
pt's amlodipine was uptitrated and home atenolol discontinued in 
favor of imdur for blood pressure control. Home aspirin was 
continued as well. In the future should pt have continued chest 
pain or ST changes would give consideration to vasospastic 
angina.
.
#CAD - h/o CAD s/p stent to the proximal RCA in ___. Clean 
coronaries per cath ___. Pt was maintained on aspirin, and 
simvastatin. Home atenolol was discontinued out of concern for 
exacerbating vasospasm. 
.  
#  Hyponatremia - initially with Na of 130. Sodium remained 
stable at this level, pt asx, and it was felt attributable to 
his hydrochlorothiazide with possibly some component of 
decreased PO intake in the setting of chest pain. 
.  
# leukocytosis - pt presented with WBC of 13.9, attributable to 
myocardial ischemia or stress response. Pt did not have any 
localizing signs of infection, WBC trended down immediately and 
he was never febrile. 
.
# HTN - Pt remained normotensive - home amlodipine was 
uptitrated, atenolol DCd in favor of imdur. ___ was discharged 
also on lisinopril (previous home med). 
.  
#GERD - continued home omeprazole.
.
Pt was maintained as FULL CODE throughout the course of this 
hospitalization.

Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure taking care of you during your recent 
hospitalization. You came in with chest pain. Some changes on 
your EKG suggested it might be related to a problem with your 
heart so a cardiac catheterization was performed. This showed 
that you did not have any blockages in the arteries that supply 
your heart. We think that you might have a little bit of 
irritation of the lining around the heart which could cause this 
pain, or also likely is that one of the arteries had a brief 
spasm which constricted blood flow to the heart.

Pathology: Liver, needle core biopsy:
1.  Moderate portal, periportal, and lobular mixed inflammation, 
consisting of lymphocytes, focally prominent plasma cells, 
neutrophils, and rare eosinophils, with numerous apoptotic 
hepatocytes (Grade 2).
2.  Prominent lobular disarray and regeneration with scattered 
lymphohistiocytic aggregates.
3.  No steatosis or balloon cell degeneration is identified.
4.  Trichrome stain demonstrates mildly increased portal 
fibrosis with focal, early septa formation (Stage 1 - 2). 
5.  Iron stain is negative for iron deposition.  
Note:  The features are those of a chronic, markedly active 
hepatitis, consistent with the provided clinical history of 
previously documented autoimmune hepatitis.  Other causes of 
chronic active hepatitis such as due to viral or drug-related 
etiologies remain within the histologic differential. 

___ U/S: 1. Partially contracted gallbladder without 
evidence of stone and no acute cholecystitis. 2. Splenomegaly. 
3. Borderline echogenic liver compatible with minimal fatty 
infiltrates. No focal hepatic lesions. 
 
Brief Hospital Course:
#. Abdominal pain: Liver biopsy found to be consistent with 
autoimmune hepatitis. The patient was restarted on prednisone & 
azathioprine therapy. Viral serologies were negative. No focal 
lesions were seen on U/S. The patient required frequent 
reassurance in response to her anxiety regarding the emotional 
effect that prednisone was going to have. Her LFTs trended 
downwards while on prednisone and azathioprine, and she was 
discharged with close hepatology follow up and instructions for 
a further prednisone taper. 
.  
# Anemia: Iron studies were consistent with iron deficiency 
anemia. The patient was restarted on iron supplementation, a 
recommendation which had been documented on past discharge 
summaries, obtained from outside hospitals.

FINDINGS: There are multiple enhancing masses, suspicious for 
metastatic  disease. The largest mass in the right frontal lobe 
measures 2.5 x 2 cm with a rim of contrast extending beyond the 
borders of the lesion consistent with blood brain barrier 
breakdown. There is significant associated vasogenic edema and 
mass effect on the frontal horn of the right lateral ventricle. 
The second largest lesion is a 1.5 x 1.3 cm enhancing mass in 
left gyrus rectus, also with significant vasogenic edema. 
Additional lesions include: an 0.8 cm ovoid lesion in the right 
prefrontal cortex, 0.5 cm lesion in the left parietal lobe, and 
a 0.6 cm lesion in the right temporal lobe. Additionally, there 
are several other tiny foci of enhancement which are too small 
to further characterize and should be followed closely on future 
exams. There is no leptomeningeal enhancement. 
  
There is no evidence of hemorrhage or infarction. No areas of 
restricted diffusion. There is no hydrocephalus and the basal 
cisterns are preserved. The calvarium and soft tissues are 
normal. A mucous retention cyst within the right maxillary sinus 
is noted. 
  
IMPRESSION: Multiple enhancing lesions within both cerebral 
hemispheres, most likely representing metastatic disease. These 
lesions have significant vasogenic edema and there is mass 
effect on the right lateral ventricle.

Brief Hospital Course:
___ woman with a h/o ___ transferred from OSH with 
angioedema s/p intubation for airway protection.

# Angioedema: Ms. ___ presented to ___ with 
tongue swelling c/w angioedema and was intubated for airway 
protection without clear report of respiratory distress or 
stridor/wheezing. The etiology for angioedema is not entirely 
clear. This is first event and she was not taking an ACEI. 
NSAIDs are the medication she is on that could be associated 
with angioedema, and she did take Motrin the night prior to 
developing facial and tongue swelling. Estrogens can also be 
associated so her OCP could be a rare culprit, so her OCPs were 
discontinued during this hospitalization. 

Her symptoms are mostly isolated angioedema and she does not 
have report of concurrent symptoms to suggest an allergic 
process associated with mast cell activation such 
pruritis/flushing or uricaria. This suggests more likely a 
bradykinin-mediated process. Given her young age and isolated 
angioedema, can also consider possibility of C1 inhibitor 
deficiency so C1 inhibitor level sent off. 

Therapeutically, she was given methylprednisone, IV benadryl and 
IV pepcid. Her swelling improved and she was extubated on 
hospital day 1. She was monitored for an additional 24 hours, 
and discharged with normal appearing oropharynx and tongue. 
NSAIDs were added to her allergy list and OCPs discontinued. She 
was clearly instructed to avoid these medications going forward, 
and she endorsed understanding of this recommendation. She will 
coordinate future birth control with her primary care physician 
and partner.

# Hyperthyroidism: There is no known association of methimazole 
with angioedema so home methimazole was continued.

# Menometrorrhagia: She has a h/o abnormal periods per report 
from her uncle, and is on OCPs. Uterus is palpable on exam so 
her abnormal periods may be related to fibroids. Urine pregnancy 
test was negative.

>> transitional issues:
- f/u with PCP ___ 1 week, consider out-patient Allergy 
evaluation
- New allergy: NSAIDs
- Studies pending at time of discharge: C1 inhibitor

Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure taking care of you in the hospital. You were 
admitted with swelling of your tongue, which is a condition that 
we call angioedema. You had a breathing tube put in to protect 
your airway because of the swelling. You were monitored in the 
intensive care unit on the breathing machine until the swelling 
decreased and then your breathing tube was removed. 

The cause of your tongue swelling is not entirely clear. It is 
very important to not take any medications like ibuprofen, 
aleve, naproxen, or other NSAID medications as they may have 
contributed to this swelling. You can take tylenol but you 
should call your doctor before taking any new medication to be 
sure that it will not cross-react with ibrofen like medications.

If you experience any repeated swelling in your tongue, lips or 
face or difficulty breathing, return to the emergency department 
IMMEDIATELY!
